title: Croatian Ecuadorians
text:
Croatian Ecuadorians are <a href="Ecuadorian">Ecuadorian</a>s who are descended from migrants from <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>. There are approximately 4,000 <a href="Croats">Croats</a> and their descendants living in <a href="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>. One can mention two major periods of the <a href="immigration">immigration</a> of Croats to <a href="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>; the first one at the end of the 19th century and the early 20th century and the recent that started in the 1990s. During the first period, <a href="Croat">Croat</a> <a href="immigrants">immigrants</a> were moistly traders from <a href="Dubrovnik">Dubrovnik</a>, <a href="Split%2C%20Croatia">Split</a> and the <a href="island">island</a> of <a href="Vis%20%28island%29">Vis</a> who settled in <a href="agricultural">agricultural</a> parts of Ecuador, especially in the region of <a href="Manab%C3%AD%20Province">Manabí</a>, and in the cities such <a href="Bahia%20De%20Caraquez">Bahia De Caraquez</a>, <a href="Chone%2C%20Ecuador">Chone</a>, <a href="Manta%2C%20Ecuador">Manta</a>, <a href="Portoviejo">Portoviejo</a> and <a href="Guayaquil">Guayaquil</a>, <a href="Cuenca%2C%20Ecuador">Cuenca</a> and <a href="Quito">Quito</a>.
The current <a href="immigration">immigration</a> of Croats began with their arrival in Ecuador and was largely motivated by the interest in the <a href="fish%20industry">fish industry</a> and the <a href="exploration">exploration</a> of marine <a href="crustaceans">crustaceans</a>. Most of these new immigrants come from the <a href="Adriatic%20coast">Adriatic coast</a>, especially from Split, and are employed in the <a href="tuna">tuna</a> and <a href="sardines">sardines</a> processing industry. Ecuadorian Croats and their descendants have a high cultural and economic <a href="Socioeconomic%20status">status</a> in the society and are quite prominent, particularly in the <a href="agricultural">agricultural</a> and <a href="fishing">fishing</a> field, as well as in <a href="commerce">commerce</a> and <a href="Industrial%20sector">industry</a>.
Ecuador has a large fleet of ships for banana transportation; also fish and merchant vessels whose crew is also made up of <a href="Croats">Croats</a> living in <a href="Guayaquil">Guayaquil</a>. They are, however, not registered as <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>n <a href="immigrants">immigrants</a>.
In 2004 an association was established in Ecuador where Croats and their descendants often congregate. Included are <a href="Istro-Romanians">Istro-Romanians</a>, who became adjusted to Ecuadorian society because of the linguistic similarities between <a href="Istro-Romanian%20language">Istro-Romanian</a> and <a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish</a>, as well as <a href="Romance-speaking%20Europe">Latin identity</a> of Istro-Romanians.
